awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Food-Water-Energy Nexus: Integrated analysis and modeling for the management of sustainable urban Food Water Energy Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This project seeks to develop a shared urban data and modeling framework to help cities analyze and characterize FWE systems and nexus interrelationships.  The framework will utilize a common urban 3D data model that will be shaped by urban stakeholder requirements and be applicable to regions and cities in Europe and the United States.  This framework will help stakeholders identify, quantify and visualize cross-sectoral and cross-media impacts to FWE systems from various decisions -- from urban development strategies to FEW infrastructure investments.  The results will provide data that can help cities across the globe sustainably provide energy, water and food supplies under healthy and economically productive conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
1. Development of a shared urban data and modeling framework in three case studies of different urban density to analyze and characterize the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) systems and their nexus interrelationships. 

The IN-SOURCE project team has developed an urban data and modeling framework based on the CityGML standard to help cities and municipalities analyse and characterise FWE systems and their nexus relationships (lead HFT). The common 3D data model for cities and regions in Europe and the U.S. thus was made applicable to the case studies of Ludwigsburg/Germany, Vienna and New York City. The new CityGML Food-Water-Energy Application Domain Extention (FWE ADE) supports a cross-sectoral data model as required for FWE-Nexus related simulations. Based on this, several food-water-energy simulations were developed for the SimStadt simulation platform. Here the FWE ADE serves as a data storage model for storing the inputs and outputs of the simulations and as a data visualisation model for the web visualisation of the simulation results.

AIT performed land use change scenario simulations for urban agriculture, driven by the expected population growth in Vienna, the climate impact for urban agriculture and the water demand. BOKU further quantified the Human Appropriation of Net Primary Production (HANPP), a socio-ecological indicator that depicts the appropriation of biomass. This enables to analyse environmental consequences of urban land use. 

Underlying calculators and web-based tools were developed in New York for carbon-foot-printing of dietary habits and of electrical demand for last-mile food distribution with electrification of trucking.

A number of classical analyses in the areas of food, energy and water/wastewater accompanied and supported the development of the tools in the form of student project work, bachelor's and master's theses for all three case studies.

Basic analyses and a benchmarking methodology for all case studies in the area of water reuse/sector coupling/BtX, have been carried out by partner AHC. For Ludwigsburg, for example, a high potential is seen for the production of biomethane and the reuse of treated wastewater.

2.  Stakeholder activation and involvement 

Parallel to the technical developments and analyses, a co-creation process with stakeholders was initiated through which their expertise and analysis requirements could be incorporated into the project. The IN-SOURCE stakeholder involvement ranged from the transdisciplinary vision building, qualitative system analysis over the working process in each case study and feedback on results to large scale replication and dissemination and was led by the case study leaders. Each national team developed a methodical process of stakeholder activation and workshop designs. Visions and future scenarios were elaborated in a co-creation process, supported by visualisations via a 3D web application (see The Vis Toolbox).

In Vienna, FWE Land Use scenarios were presented and discussed in the final part of a workshop series, that started with vision building. The Austrian worked with stakeholders from the city administration (energy + water), from private and public food production and consumption bodies including civil society and NGOs to cooperate with the scientists in the field of FWE nexus.

In Germany, water re-use and a secure and healthy food supply were discussed as a priority, led by LKR and AHC. More detailed simulation workflows concerning water supply and biomass potentials in the (competing) food and energy sectors were elaborated by HFT. 

In New York, the team has seen its CityGML-based net-zero/carbon-neutral community modelling, become of significant interest and value to community participants, city planners, and institutional partners such as the Urban Land Institute, applying the models to topics of the day, such as urban heat-island. Use of EU-developed tools for biomass and food production speaks to local food security and nutrition, especially during the pandemic. The less quantitative approach to wastewater treatment facilities, emphasizing integration of sustainability functions via visualization and site programming, has gained initial adoption from institutional stakeholder DEP and interest from organizers engaged with local community organizing and participatory planning.

In New York two distinct types of stakeholder engagement case study were continued: community-based, in the Gowanus district (NYIT) and agency-based, with the NYC Dept of Environmental Protection/Bureau of Wastewater (DEP/BWT) (CUNY).

3.  The VisToolbox

All interactive tools and additional information and guidelines were embedded in publicly accessible websites.  

A Vis Toolbox, embedded in the homepage of the Austrian partner AIT, contains the interactive tools: 3D viewers of each case study and the HANPP and Food eHANPP Explorer. Additionally, information on AIT's FEW Land Use Simulator and Causal Loop Diagram, HFT's FEW ADE + SimStadt workflows, NYIT's CO2-Boo (tracking the carbon footprint of users diets), CUNY's Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility Planning Guide and a quiz for each case study region.

Vistoolbox Collection AIT: https://drc.ait.ac.at/sites/insource

The 3D viewers and a description on SimStadt and the FEW ADE can be found at HFT Transfer portal: IN-Source: FWE Simulation Tool (hft-stuttgart.de)

The 3D Demo of all 3 case studies:

Ludwigsburg District: https://transfer.hft-stuttgart.de/pages/in-source/lkrludwigsburg3d/

Meidling/Vienna: https://transfer.hft-stuttgart.de/pages/in-source/meidling-3d-viewer/

Gowanus/New York City: https://transfer.hft-stuttgart.de/pages/in-source/gowanus-citygml-viewer/
